messageBody:
I actually have a related question:

What if you want to wrapper the befores and afters too? In my case,
I'd like to wrapper the whole sequence of befores, the test and the
afters. Is overriding JUnit4ClassRunner.invokeTestMethod(Method,
RunNotifier) a reasonable way to do this? Is there a better way?

Thanks!


-phil



--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <saff@...> wrote:
>
> Oops. That code will only work in the current 4.5-snapshot. This
> will work in 4.4, 4.5, and beyond:
>
> public static class Mocks extends JUnit4ClassRunner {
> public Mocks(Class<?> klass) throws InitializationError {
> super(klass);
> }
>
> @Override
> protected TestMethod wrapMethod(Method method) {
> return new TestMethod(method, getTestClass()) {
> @Override
> protected void invoke(Object test)
> throws
IllegalArgumentException,
> IllegalAccessException,
> InvocationTargetException {
> super.invoke(test);
> verifyMocks();
> }
> };
> }
> }
>
> Thanks,
>
> David Saff
>
> On 7/23/07, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
> > Nat,
> >
> > Extending internals of your dependencies in order to give your users a
> > better experience is a fact of life. With 4.4, we took one step
> > toward a more extensible design for JUnit4ClassRunner. In the next
> > version, we hope to finish, and stabilize, the object structure, so
> > that extenders can depend on it. The way to do what you want in JUnit
> > 4.4 and beyond should look like this:
> >
> > public static class Mocks extends JUnit4ClassRunner {
> > public Mocks(Class<?> klass) throws
InitializationError {
> > super(klass);
> > }
> >
> > @Override
> > protected TestMethod wrapMethod(Method method) {
> > return new TestMethod(method,
getTestClass()) {
> > @Override
> > protected void invoke(Roadie context)
> > throws
IllegalArgumentException,
> >
IllegalAccessException, InvocationTargetException {
> > super.invoke(context);
> > verifyMocks();
> > }
> > };
> > }
> > }
> >
> > The Roadie class is new in 4.4: it sets up for the test, tears down
> > after the test, and records what's going on while the test is
> > performing. (For cultural background to the metaphor, see:
> > http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roadie)
> >
> > Thanks,
> >
> > David Saff
> >
> > On 7/23/07, Nat Pryce <nat.pryce@...> wrote:
> > > Hi all.
> > >
> > > It's our own fault I know, but the new JUnit 4.4 release breaks
jMock
> > > 2 because we extended the internal runner classes to verify mock
> > > objects at the end of the test but before the @After methods are
> > > called to tear down the fixtures.
> > >
> > > The classes we extended no longer exist. What's the new,
approved way
> > > of doing this?
> > >
> > > --Nat
